snippet: Richard G. Lugar, one of the Senate’s longest-serving members, lost a hard-fought Republican primary to Richard E. Mourdock, the Indiana state treasurer.
abstract: Indiana's six-term Sen Richard G Lugar, one of the Senate's longest-serving members, loses a hard-fought Republican primary to Richard E Mourdock, the state treasurer; Mourdock's campaign was fueled by Tea Party groups and national conservative organizations that deemed collegial moderate Lugar too willing to compromise. Photos, Chart (M)0

byline.original: By MONICA DAVEY; Carl Hulse and Jennifer Steinhauer contributed reporting from Washington

lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS -- Richard G. Lugar, one of the Senate's longest-serving members, a collegial moderate who personified a gentler political era, was turned out of office on Tuesday, ending a career that had spanned the terms of half a dozen presidents. Mr. Lugar, a six-term senator from Indiana who had won most of his recent elections with more than 60 percent of the vote, lost a hard-fought Republican primary to Richard E. Mourdock, the state treasurer. Mr. Mourdock's campaign was fueled by Tea Party groups and national conservative organizations that deemed Mr. Lugar too willing to compromise and poured millions of dollars into the campaign to defeat him.

headline.main: G.O.P. Voters Topple Lugar After 6 Terms
